map_node.indicator_description: Violence is frequently described through homicide statistics. While it is a leading cause of death and captures the most severe form of violence, non-fatal violence-related injuries resulting in hospitalizations are much more common and help paint the larger picture on the burden of violence and its impact on the health and future of individuals, families, and communities.

dataset.how_calculated: Counts were calculated as described above and summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
dataset.discription: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

dataset.how_calculated: Number of NYC non-fatal assault hospitalizations among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only.
dataset.discription: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

unreliable_text: *** Number is suppressed for confidentiality reasons.

show_disparities_node.disparitiesPagetext: When population health or the quality of living environments varies by population characteristics such as income or race, there is disparity. One way to visualize disparity is to chart indicators of health or environment across levels of neighborhood poverty. We categorized neighborhoods as high, medium or low poverty. Then we took the median of the neighborhood-specific values in each category. The median is the middle of the sorted group of values.

info.info_how_calculated: Counts were calculated as described above and summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
info.info_source: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

info.info_how_calculated: Neighborhoods are ranked according to the percent of people whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level. Rankings are then divided into 3 approximately equal groupings of low, medium and high poverty.

summarize_data.indicator_description: Violence is frequently described through homicide statistics. While it is a leading cause of death and captures the most severe form of violence, non-fatal violence-related injuries resulting in hospitalizations are much more common and help paint the larger picture on the burden of violence and its impact on the health and future of individuals, families, and communities.
